content: Get a planner, calendar and/or a bullet journal. Whether it's a day planner you carry in your backpack, a calendar on your wall at home, a to-do list you make at the end of every day, or an online calendar, it can help you keep track of when assignments are due and stay organized. At the beginning of the term, when you get your planner, note down every test, quiz, and assignment due date. Do this for each class. Every day when you get home from school, check your calendar and see what needs to be done before tomorrow, as well as what's on the horizon for the next few days. Check off what you have already done. Get an expandable file and put in the labels. Put your papers in the file so that you always have the correct things at the correct times. Keep the file in your bag, desk, or locker, whichever is most convenient. Organize your locker / backpack / desk . Organizing whatever you use every day helps your mind feel clutter-free. It may sound silly, but when your visual environment is simple and orderly, your mind can concentrate on the more important stuff. Once a week, clean out your locker or backpack and organize your desk. It only takes a couple minutes. You won't lose things when you automatically put them where they belong. Having a backpack, desk, or locker that's full of loose papers just gets confusing and frustrating. Make a study schedule . You have a calendar for the week or month, but you need a weekly study schedule, too. Map out your week to see when your studying can and should get done. That way you know just how much time you can devote to each class and when it makes the most sense to study for each one. Make sure that you abide by the plans that you make. Use your common sense when it comes to allotting time to specific classes. For example, Badminton needs a lot less time than Principles of Celestial Mechanics. Make sure you have an agenda so that you can write down all of your tests, when you have to study, and when you have homework due. Know your learning style . The matter of fact is that certain techniques don't work for certain people. Some of us learn with our hands, some of us with our eyes, and some of us with our ears (and others a combination). If you can't remember a thing your professor said, maybe you're just going about it the wrong way. Once you find out your learning style, you can zone in on what's best for you. Do you remember best the things you've seen? Then study those notes and make graphs! The things you've heard? Go to class and record those lectures. Things you do with your hands? Turn the concepts into something you can build. Read the textbook. As much as it is boring and monotonous, it is incredibly useful -- sometimes professors don't even mention the info in class! After reading a paragraph, revise it in your head without looking. Then read it again. It will stay in your mind for a longer time. It is particularly effective when you have less time for studying. Often the things mentioned in class that are also mentioned in the book are the most important. If you run across some of this while reading, highlight it. You'll want to know where it is to find it later. Don't write off the benefits of scanning. Concentrating on the main ideas (the highlighted text, italics, etc.) will get your mind going. [1] If you can fill in the blanks, great! If you can't, read deeper. Take good notes. For most courses in middle school, high school, and junior/community college, most of what is on the tests and homework will be discussed in the class. If your teacher draws a diagram on the board, copy that down - it can help you remember the information. Write good, legible notes. Use highlighters if there's something you need to find easily flipping through your notes, but don't highlight too much text or it defeats the purpose. Colored pens are fun to write with if you want to get more creative with your notes, but use them only for sections of your notes that you feel will be on a test or are important. Study effectively . Wasting nights pouring over books and emerging feeling like you've gotten nothing out of it is just about the worst. Instead of falling asleep over your textbook, try the following: Make a study guide and review it. Look in the textbook and put all important ideas and details in your notes. Go over it until you feel like you know the material well. If you've written it, you'll probably remember more of it. Make someone test you on the study guide. Talking about the information out loud is a lot easier to retain than going over the same stuff in your brain over and over. When you have to explain it to someone else, it forces you to understand it, not just know it. Invent fun ways to study. Make flash cards, have a friend over, or join an after-school homework club if you can for help from a teacher or friend from the same class. You can make a board game to make studying fun and easy, or you can just type up your notes if it makes it easier to read. Do as much as possible to make sure you know the material. Participate in class. You've done your homework, so you're totally prepared to participate in class. Show that you know your stuff! There are a few reasons this is a good idea. The most important one is that participating in class will cement in your head the stuff you learned from doing your homework (before it was more like Jell-O). The second good reason is that it will cement the information in your brain. Seriously. Talking about it out loud (especially in class, where it's a bit more stressful than when with a friend) uses a different part of your brain than just writing about it. This way, you're covering all your bases. The third good reason is that your professor will totally appreciate it. No teacher likes a room full of crickets. Get on their good side, and you'll get treated better when grade time comes around or when you ask for extra credit. Ask for help. If you're not sure what's required for a good grade or are struggling with the coursework, ask your teacher for help. It doesn't have to be a complex question; your teacher is always happy to help you. Ask after class, during office hours, or in an e-mail for assistance. [2] Often things we're told one-on-one stick with us more than things we're just being lectured about. In addition to the personalized learning session, your teacher will appreciate your efforts and straight up probably like you more. Having a teacher that likes you can come in very, very, very handy. Get a tutor. If in the end the subject is super hard, and you just can't understand it, get a tutor to help you. Sometimes a tutor is even more helpful than getting a one-on-one with a teacher because they are closer to your age and can explain things to you in a manner that you can understand better. Do your homework immediately after school. Time management is essential. If you're given an assignment that's due next week, don't procrastinate; get started within a few days of receiving the assignment. The more time you have, the less you'll stress. If possible, try to get assignments finished at least two or three days before the due date. This is to avoid last-minute emergencies, like "the dog eating your paper," a party invitation, the printer running out of ink, illness, family emergency, etc. Most teachers will deduct points for each day your work is late. Some do not accept late papers at all. If it helps you, try handing in your homework a couple days before it's due. Homework counts for a large portion of your grade. If your teacher has any extra credit assignments, do them! It won't hurt if you try it out. Even if you get some wrong, your teachers will still notice your effort to try to learn more. Get help from others. If you do not understand your homework, it's a good idea to write down any questions that you need to know and ask your teacher after politely. Join extra classes too it will help you get better grades fast. Get tutor lessons. If you cannot afford a tutor, your teacher will help you for free if she or he wants to. Put homework first. Set yourself goals and make sure you reach them before you go out and party. Having a social life is important, but your grades can affect a lot of your choices for the future. Schedule time each day to study, just as you would schedule dates or parties. You can reward yourself for getting your homework done! Once you've completed it, it's TV, food, or party time. If that's not enough, ask if mom or dad can help you get incentivized. They want you to get good grades, too! Work with friends. Studying for tests with friends is super beneficial, so why not do homework with friends, too?! Not only will you stay motivated (and possibly stay interested in the class), but you'll be able to combine your levels of awesome and get things done more quickly, effectively, and possibly creatively. The key here is to choose a friend that will pull his/her weight. You don't want to work with a friend that expects you to do all the work. Nor do you want a friend that wants neither of you to work! Choose a friend that's as goal-oriented as you are. Don't plagiarize. The quickest way to get a zero on an assignment is to plagiarize it. Technology is amazing nowadays and your teacher will know if you're plagiarizing. Whether it's Google Translate or a speech by Martin Luther King, Jr., they'll know. So don't risk it. Study with a friend. There is strength in numbers, even when it comes to studying. Bouncing ideas off each other and combining knowledge is a resource that is invaluable. Just make sure you don't distract each other or spend your whole time chatting with each other about the day! This takes the information off the page and makes it fun and memorable. When you have to explain something to a friend, your brain has to wrap around it, instead of just taking it in and hoping that it stays. Make flashcards and study guides for each other to cover all the material. Use memory tricks. Things like mnemonic devices can really trigger information that doesn't otherwise want to stick. Odds are you probably know Roy G. Biv for the order of the colors of the rainbow or "My very exhausted mother just slept until noon." for the order of the planets. Why is that? They're effective mnemonic devices that stick in your mind! Associations work, too. If you're trying to remember that India used to be a British colony, picture the queen jogging laps around the Taj Mahal. When the test comes, you may not remember what you actually should remember, but you'll remember enough to jog your memory! Study in the places that you feel comfortable in. You need a good, calm place to study. Make sure you have a sweater in case it gets cold, a good, comfy chair, some dark chocolate (brain power! [3] ), a bottle of water, and whatever else you may need. That way, you'll have few interruptions. Research also shows that you should study in more than one place. It sounds a little funny, but your brain makes associations with your environment. So, the more associations it has, the more likely you are to retain the information. Locate all the comfy chairs and study in them all! Stop cramming. Although it's inevitable sometimes, cramming isn't the way to go. In fact, taking breaks is good for your brain and will help you retain more . Try to study in 20-50 minute intervals, taking five or ten minutes in between. [4] If you're on top of things, it's best to study over a full week. Several sessions will cement the knowledge in your head and by the end you'll be able to notice how much better you know the content, allowing you to relax and be confident. Relax. Easier said than done? Remember - you have all of the answers in your head already! The only challenge is getting them out! Your first instinct is nearly always correct. Don't go back and change answers. If you are really not sure, skip it and come back later. Always read the questions given on a test. Skimming over them might tell you the opposite of what you need to do. If you're uncertain about the wording of a test question, go and ask the teacher what it means. As long as you don't flat out ask for the answer to a question, just what they meant by the question; they will usually answer. Get a good night's rest. You need sleep in order to stay focused, and without it, you will have a hard time staying on task and may forget what you just learned. That's part of the reason why cramming is so evil! Sleep is wonderful. Sleep deprivation can lead to accidents, dumbs you down, and can actually cause health problems. [5] If you have to choose between one last cramming session and sleep, choose sleep. Choose the right classes. In college, though sometimes in high school too, it's tempting to choose classes that look super impressive or are just plain out of your reach. While taking difficult classes is great and you'll learn a lot, limit it to one or two. If all you have is rocket science, you're bound to get overwhelmed. Take Rocket Science 101 and Sand Volleyball. Your brain deserves the break! Choose the right amount of classes, too. Being absolutely time-swamped won't do you any favors. When will you study? Stick to the normal amount (4 or 5 classes per semester for college) and do well in those. It's better to do well in a few than to do mediocre in many. Get to class on time. The simplest way to get good grades is just to show up to class in the first place. Not only will you get the credit for attendance (hopefully), but you won't miss any imperative announcements, concepts the professor stresses, or bonus questions the teacher includes in class (sneaky buggers, aren't they?). If you're ever on the borderline between grades, going to class will help you . Professors often look at attendance to see if the student's grade should be rounded up or down in questionable circumstances. Give yourself the benefit of the doubt and go! Eat a good, healthy breakfast every day. It is known that if students eat a good and healthy breakfast every morning, they generally get good grades and are able to focus better in school. [6] Even if you're not hungry early in the morning, bring something with you for later. You want to be not hungry -- not stuffed to the brim and sick. Instead of a six-egg omelet, go for a bowl of cereal and an orange. You'll feel more able to focus on your studies instead of that rock in your stomach. Improve your memory with games. Give your brain a workout - try some fun puzzle exercises every day such as crosswords, Sudoku, and other games which are easy enough for anyone to do. This will boost your brainpower and you will be able to memorize more information at school. Websites like Lumosity [7] and Memorize [8] are great resources! Memorize even lets you input your own information to learn! Use your time wisely. If you are given an hour to complete a 120-question test, that's 30 seconds per question. 30 seconds can be made into a lot of time. Many of the questions will take far less than 30 seconds, so apply the balance to a tougher question. Don't think too deeply on the time, and don't let yourself get distracted by the ticking of the clock. Time limits are sometimes arbitrary. If you really need an extra 5 minutes, ask. A diligent student that needs a bit more time is a concession most teachers will be willing to make. Don't be afraid to be great. Don't worry if people think you are a perfectionist or an overachiever. Be persistent with your work while everyone else is fooling around in class. In a few years you will more than likely never see these people again, but you will see the A's and B's on your transcript that could have been C's and D's if you hadn't practiced!

<h1 class="firstHeading no_toc"><a href="https://www.wikihow.com/Get-Good-Grades">How to Get Good Grades</a></h1>
<div class="ss_check" id="expert_coauthor">
	
	Co-authored by <a class="staff_icon expert_coauthor_link" href="#article_info_section">
		wikiHow Staff</a>
</div>

Together, they cited information from <a href="#references">8 references</a>. <br/><br/>wikiHow's <a href="/Special:ArticleReviewers#wikihow%20content%20team%20managers">Content Management Team</a> carefully monitors the work from our editorial staff to ensure that each article meets our high quality standards.
		<a class="sp_learn_more_link" href="/wikiHow:About-wikiHow#Why_should_you_choose_wikiHow_first.3F_sub">Learn more...</a>

</div>
<p>Everybody can get good grades no matter who you are. You need to take school seriously because it may affect your whole future. Success in school matters a lot for those who want to start early on going to the best schools, getting the best jobs, and making the most of themselves and is what determines everything. To start piling on the A's now, read on!</p>

<h2 class="hidden"><span class="mw-headline" id="Steps">Steps</span></h2>
<a class="anchor" name="Getting_Organized_sub"></a><div class="section steps sticky steps_first">
<h3>
<div class="altblock">Part <span>1</span>
</div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="Getting_Organized">Getting Organized</span>
</h3>
<div class="section_text" id="steps_1">
<ol class="steps_list_2">
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Organize-Your-Locker-in-Middle-School-(Girls)-Step-8.jpg?ajax=true&aid=16184" href="#/Image:Organize-Your-Locker-in-Middle-School-(Girls)-Step-8.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Organize Your Locker in Middle School (Girls) Step 8" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/6e/Organize-Your-Locker-in-Middle-School-%28Girls%29-Step-8.jpg/aid16184-v4-728px-Organize-Your-Locker-in-Middle-School-%28Girls%29-Step-8.jpg" height="546" id="img_4342aeb21b" onload="WH.performance.clearMarks('image1_rendered'); WH.performance.mark('image1_rendered');" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_4342aeb21b')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Organize Your Locker in Middle School (Girls) Step 8" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" onload="WH.performance.clearMarks('image1_rendered'); WH.performance.mark('image1_rendered');" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/6e/Organize-Your-Locker-in-Middle-School-%28Girls%29-Step-8.jpg/aid16184-v4-728px-Organize-Your-Locker-in-Middle-School-%28Girls%29-Step-8.jpg" width="728"/></noscript>
<script>WH.performance.clearMarks('image1_rendered'); WH.performance.mark('image1_rendered');</script></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 1" class="step_num">1</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_1"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Get a planner, calendar and/or a bullet journal.</b> Whether it's a day planner you carry in your backpack, a calendar on your wall at home, a to-do list you make at the end of every day, or an online calendar, it can help you keep track of when assignments are due and stay organized. At the beginning of the term, when you get your planner, note down every test, quiz, and assignment due date. Do this for each class.

<ul>
<li>Every day when you get home from school, check your calendar and see what needs to be done before tomorrow, as well as what's on the horizon for the next few days. Check off what you have already done.</li>
</ul>
<script>WH.performance.mark('step1_rendered');</script>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Organize-Your-Binder-for-School-Step-5-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=16184" href="#/Image:Organize-Your-Binder-for-School-Step-5-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Organize Your Binder for School Step 5" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/28/Organize-Your-Binder-for-School-Step-5-Version-2.jpg/aid16184-v4-728px-Organize-Your-Binder-for-School-Step-5-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_eb27a3790c" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_eb27a3790c')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Organize Your Binder for School Step 5" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/28/Organize-Your-Binder-for-School-Step-5-Version-2.jpg/aid16184-v4-728px-Organize-Your-Binder-for-School-Step-5-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 2" class="step_num">2</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_2"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Get an expandable file and put in the labels.</b> Put your papers in the file so that you always have the correct things at the correct times. Keep the file in your bag, desk, or locker, whichever is most convenient.

</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Get-Organized-for-School-Step-8.jpg?ajax=true&aid=16184" href="#/Image:Get-Organized-for-School-Step-8.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Get Organized for School Step 8" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/41/Get-Organized-for-School-Step-8.jpg/aid16184-v4-728px-Get-Organized-for-School-Step-8.jpg" height="546" id="img_def79a5681" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_def79a5681')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Get Organized for School Step 8" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/41/Get-Organized-for-School-Step-8.jpg/aid16184-v4-728px-Get-Organized-for-School-Step-8.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 3" class="step_num">3</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_3"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb"><a href="/Organize-Your-Locker" title="Organize Your Locker">Organize your locker</a>/<a href="/Organize-Your-Backpack" title="Organize Your Backpack">backpack</a>/<a href="/Organize-Your-Desk" title="Organize Your Desk">desk</a>.</b> Organizing whatever you use every day helps your mind feel clutter-free. It may sound silly, but when your visual environment is simple and orderly, your mind can concentrate on the more important stuff. Once a week, clean out your locker or backpack and organize your desk. It only takes a couple minutes.
<ul>
<li>You won't lose things when you automatically put them where they belong. Having a backpack, desk, or locker that's full of loose papers just gets confusing and frustrating.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Develop-a-Morning-Routine-(Teens)-Step-4-Version-3.jpg?ajax=true&aid=16184" href="#/Image:Develop-a-Morning-Routine-(Teens)-Step-4-Version-3.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Develop a Morning Routine (Teens) Step 4" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/82/Develop-a-Morning-Routine-%28Teens%29-Step-4-Version-3.jpg/aid16184-v4-728px-Develop-a-Morning-Routine-%28Teens%29-Step-4-Version-3.jpg" height="546" id="img_0851d4de94" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_0851d4de94')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Develop a Morning Routine (Teens) Step 4" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/82/Develop-a-Morning-Routine-%28Teens%29-Step-4-Version-3.jpg/aid16184-v4-728px-Develop-a-Morning-Routine-%28Teens%29-Step-4-Version-3.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 4" class="step_num">4</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_4"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb"><a href="/Create-a-Study-Schedule" title="Create a Study Schedule">Make a study schedule</a>.</b> You have a calendar for the week or month, but you need a weekly study schedule, too. Map out your week to see when your studying can and should get done. That way you know just how much time you can devote to each class and when it makes the most sense to study for each one. Make sure that you abide by the plans that you make.

<ul>
<li>Use your common sense when it comes to allotting time to specific classes. For example, Badminton needs a lot less time than Principles of Celestial Mechanics.</li>
<li>Make sure you have an agenda so that you can write down all of your tests, when you have to study, and when you have homework due.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>

</div>
<div class="clearall adclear"></div>
<script>WH.desktopAds.addBodyAd('methodad')</script>
</li>
</ol>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>
<a class="anchor" name="Absorbing_Information_sub"></a><div class="section steps sticky">
<h3>
<div class="altblock">Part <span>2</span>
</div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="Absorbing_Information">Absorbing Information</span>
</h3>
<div class="section_text" id="steps_2">
<ol class="steps_list_2">
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Write-a-Friendly-Letter-Step-5-Version-3.jpg?ajax=true&aid=16184" href="#/Image:Write-a-Friendly-Letter-Step-5-Version-3.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Write a Friendly Letter Step 5" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c0/Write-a-Friendly-Letter-Step-5-Version-3.jpg/aid16184-v4-728px-Write-a-Friendly-Letter-Step-5-Version-3.jpg" height="546" id="img_33effb13fb" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_33effb13fb')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Write a Friendly Letter Step 5" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c0/Write-a-Friendly-Letter-Step-5-Version-3.jpg/aid16184-v4-728px-Write-a-Friendly-Letter-Step-5-Version-3.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 1" class="step_num">1</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_1"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb"><a href="/Find-Your-Learning-Style" title="Find Your Learning Style">Know your learning style</a>.</b> The matter of fact is that certain techniques don't work for certain people. Some of us learn with our hands, some of us with our eyes, and some of us with our ears (and others a combination). If you can't remember a thing your professor said, maybe you're just going about it the wrong way.

<ul>
<li>Once you find out your learning style, you can zone in on what's best for you. Do you remember best the things you've seen? Then study those notes and make graphs! The things you've heard? Go to class and record those lectures. Things you do with your hands? Turn the concepts into something you can build.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Write-a-Good-Thesis-Step-1-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=16184" href="#/Image:Write-a-Good-Thesis-Step-1-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Write a Good Thesis Step 1" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b7/Write-a-Good-Thesis-Step-1-Version-2.jpg/aid16184-v4-728px-Write-a-Good-Thesis-Step-1-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_15a730fa79" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_15a730fa79')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Write a Good Thesis Step 1" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b7/Write-a-Good-Thesis-Step-1-Version-2.jpg/aid16184-v4-728px-Write-a-Good-Thesis-Step-1-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 2" class="step_num">2</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_2"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Read the textbook.</b> As much as it is boring and monotonous, it is incredibly useful -- sometimes professors don't even mention the info in class! After reading a paragraph, revise it in your head without looking. Then read it again. It will stay in your mind for a longer time. It is particularly effective when you have less time for studying.
<ul>
<li>Often the things mentioned in class that are also mentioned in the book are the most important. If you run across some of this while reading, highlight it. You'll want to know where it is to find it later.</li>
<li>Don't write off the benefits of scanning. Concentrating on the main ideas (the highlighted text, italics, etc.) will get your mind going.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 1" class="reference" id="_ref-1"><a href="#_note-1">[1]</a></sup> If you can fill in the blanks, great! If you can't, read deeper.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Make-a-Point-Step-3-Version-3.jpg?ajax=true&aid=16184" href="#/Image:Make-a-Point-Step-3-Version-3.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Make a Point Step 3" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/61/Make-a-Point-Step-3-Version-3.jpg/aid16184-v4-728px-Make-a-Point-Step-3-Version-3.jpg" height="546" id="img_353353e682" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_353353e682')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Make a Point Step 3" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/61/Make-a-Point-Step-3-Version-3.jpg/aid16184-v4-728px-Make-a-Point-Step-3-Version-3.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 3" class="step_num">3</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_3"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Take good notes.</b> For most courses in middle school, high school, and junior/community college, most of what is on the tests and homework will be discussed in the class. If your teacher draws a diagram on the board, copy that down - it can help you remember the information.
<ul>
<li>Write good, legible notes. Use highlighters if there's something you need to find easily flipping through your notes, but don't highlight too much text or it defeats the purpose. Colored pens are fun to write with if you want to get more creative with your notes, but use them only for sections of your notes that you feel will be on a test or are important.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Make-a-Point-Step-1-Version-3.jpg?ajax=true&aid=16184" href="#/Image:Make-a-Point-Step-1-Version-3.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Make a Point Step 1" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/8a/Make-a-Point-Step-1-Version-3.jpg/aid16184-v4-728px-Make-a-Point-Step-1-Version-3.jpg" height="546" id="img_bd997a7a56" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_bd997a7a56')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Make a Point Step 1" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/8a/Make-a-Point-Step-1-Version-3.jpg/aid16184-v4-728px-Make-a-Point-Step-1-Version-3.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 4" class="step_num">4</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_4"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb"><a href="/Study-for-College" title="Study for College">Study effectively</a>.</b> Wasting nights pouring over books and emerging feeling like you've gotten nothing out of it is just about the worst. Instead of falling asleep over your textbook, try the following:
<ul>
<li>Make a study guide and review it. Look in the textbook and put all important ideas and details in your notes. Go over it until you feel like you know the material well. If you've written it, you'll probably remember more of it.</li>
<li>Make someone test you on the study guide. Talking about the information out loud is a lot easier to retain than going over the same stuff in your brain over and over. When you have to explain it to someone else, it forces you to <i>understand</i> it, not just know it.</li>
<li>Invent fun ways to study. Make flash cards, have a friend over, or join an after-school homework club if you can for help from a teacher or friend from the same class. You can make a board game to make studying fun and easy, or you can just type up your notes if it makes it easier to read. Do as much as possible to make sure you know the material.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Be-Grown-Up-Step-10-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=16184" href="#/Image:Be-Grown-Up-Step-10-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Be Grown Up Step 10" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/82/Be-Grown-Up-Step-10-Version-2.jpg/aid16184-v4-728px-Be-Grown-Up-Step-10-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_ac27920ced" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_ac27920ced')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Be Grown Up Step 10" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/82/Be-Grown-Up-Step-10-Version-2.jpg/aid16184-v4-728px-Be-Grown-Up-Step-10-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 5" class="step_num">5</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_5"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Participate in class.</b> You've done your homework, so you're totally prepared to participate in class. Show that you know your stuff! There are a few reasons this is a good idea. The most important one is that participating in class will cement in your head the stuff you learned from doing your homework (before it was more like Jell-O).

<ul>
<li>The second good reason is that it will cement the information in your brain. Seriously. Talking about it out loud (especially in class, where it's a bit more stressful than when with a friend) uses a different part of your brain than just writing about it. This way, you're covering all your bases.</li>
<li>The third good reason is that your professor will totally appreciate it. No teacher likes a room full of crickets. Get on their good side, and you'll get treated better when grade time comes around or when you ask for extra credit.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Be-a-Good-English-Teacher-Step-18-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=16184" href="#/Image:Be-a-Good-English-Teacher-Step-18-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Be a Good English Teacher Step 18" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/7f/Be-a-Good-English-Teacher-Step-18-Version-2.jpg/aid16184-v4-728px-Be-a-Good-English-Teacher-Step-18-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_c8dda7a057" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_c8dda7a057')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Be a Good English Teacher Step 18" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/7f/Be-a-Good-English-Teacher-Step-18-Version-2.jpg/aid16184-v4-728px-Be-a-Good-English-Teacher-Step-18-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 6" class="step_num">6</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_6"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Ask for help.</b> If you're not sure what's required for a good grade or are struggling with the coursework, ask your teacher for help. It doesn't have to be a complex question; your teacher is always happy to help you. Ask after class, during office hours, or in an e-mail for assistance.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 2" class="reference" id="_ref-2"><a href="#_note-2">[2]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Often things we're told one-on-one stick with us more than things we're just being lectured about. In addition to the personalized learning session, your teacher will appreciate your efforts and straight up probably like you more. Having a teacher that likes you can come in very, very, very handy.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Be-a-Good-English-Teacher-Step-19-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=16184" href="#/Image:Be-a-Good-English-Teacher-Step-19-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Be a Good English Teacher Step 19" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/ee/Be-a-Good-English-Teacher-Step-19-Version-2.jpg/aid16184-v4-728px-Be-a-Good-English-Teacher-Step-19-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_bcb3ef5c90" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_bcb3ef5c90')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Be a Good English Teacher Step 19" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/ee/Be-a-Good-English-Teacher-Step-19-Version-2.jpg/aid16184-v4-728px-Be-a-Good-English-Teacher-Step-19-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 7" class="step_num">7</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_7"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Get a tutor.</b> If in the end the subject is super hard, and you just can't understand it, get a tutor to help you. Sometimes a tutor is even more helpful than getting a one-on-one with a teacher because they are closer to your age and can explain things to you in a manner that you can understand better.

</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
<div id="tocad_wrap">
<div class="wh_ad_inner step_ad" data-adsenseheight="90" data-adsensewidth="728" data-adtargetid="tocad" data-adunitpath="" data-aps-timeout="2000" data-channels="6381149051,4805470868" data-lateload="1" data-loaded="0" data-service="adsense" data-slot="3356467874" data-viewablerefresh="1" id="tocad_outer"><div class="step_ad" id="tocad"></div></div>
<div class="clearall adclear"></div>
<script>WH.desktopAds.addTOCAd('tocad')</script>
</div>
</li>
</ol>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>
<a class="anchor" name="Doing_Your_Homework_sub"></a><div class="section steps sticky">
<h3>
<div class="altblock">Part <span>3</span>
</div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="Doing_Your_Homework">Doing Your Homework</span>
</h3>
<div class="section_text" id="steps_3">
<ol class="steps_list_2">
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Be-a-Good-English-Teacher-Step-7-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=16184" href="#/Image:Be-a-Good-English-Teacher-Step-7-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Be a Good English Teacher Step 7" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/10/Be-a-Good-English-Teacher-Step-7-Version-2.jpg/aid16184-v4-728px-Be-a-Good-English-Teacher-Step-7-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_9ef7e11d52" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_9ef7e11d52')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Be a Good English Teacher Step 7" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/10/Be-a-Good-English-Teacher-Step-7-Version-2.jpg/aid16184-v4-728px-Be-a-Good-English-Teacher-Step-7-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 1" class="step_num">1</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_1"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Do your homework immediately after school.</b> Time management is essential. If you're given an assignment that's due next week, don't procrastinate; get started within a few days of receiving the assignment. The more time you have, the less you'll stress.
<ul>
<li>If possible, try to get assignments finished at least two or three days before the due date. This is to avoid last-minute emergencies, like "the dog eating your paper," a party invitation, the printer running out of ink, illness, family emergency, etc. Most teachers will deduct points for each day your work is late. Some do not accept late papers at all. If it helps you, try handing in your homework a couple days before it's due.</li>
<li>Homework counts for a large portion of your grade. If your teacher has any extra credit assignments, do them! It won't hurt if you try it out. Even if you get some wrong, your teachers will still notice your effort to try to <a href="/Learn" title="Learn">learn</a> more.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Get-a-Visa-to-Study-in-Belgium-Step-22.jpg?ajax=true&aid=16184" href="#/Image:Get-a-Visa-to-Study-in-Belgium-Step-22.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Get a Visa to Study in Belgium Step 22" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/4b/Get-a-Visa-to-Study-in-Belgium-Step-22.jpg/aid16184-v4-728px-Get-a-Visa-to-Study-in-Belgium-Step-22.jpg" height="546" id="img_fc2058e2e5" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_fc2058e2e5')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Get a Visa to Study in Belgium Step 22" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/4b/Get-a-Visa-to-Study-in-Belgium-Step-22.jpg/aid16184-v4-728px-Get-a-Visa-to-Study-in-Belgium-Step-22.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 2" class="step_num">2</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_2"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Get help from others.</b> If you do not understand your homework, it's a good idea to write down any questions that you need to know and ask your teacher after politely. Join extra classes too it will help you get better grades fast. Get tutor lessons. If you cannot afford a tutor, your teacher will help you for free if she or he wants to.

</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Enjoy-Being-Homeschooled-Step-14.jpg?ajax=true&aid=16184" href="#/Image:Enjoy-Being-Homeschooled-Step-14.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Enjoy Being Homeschooled Step 14" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/9c/Enjoy-Being-Homeschooled-Step-14.jpg/aid16184-v4-728px-Enjoy-Being-Homeschooled-Step-14.jpg" height="546" id="img_1c466809e9" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_1c466809e9')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Enjoy Being Homeschooled Step 14" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/9c/Enjoy-Being-Homeschooled-Step-14.jpg/aid16184-v4-728px-Enjoy-Being-Homeschooled-Step-14.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 3" class="step_num">3</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_3"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb"><a href="/Concentrate-on-Your-Homework" title="Concentrate on Your Homework">Put homework first.</a></b> Set yourself goals and make sure you reach them before you go out and party. Having a social life is important, but your grades can affect a lot of your choices for the future. Schedule time each day to study, just as you would schedule dates or parties.

<ul>
<li>You can reward yourself for getting your homework done! Once you've completed it, it's TV, food, or party time. If that's not enough, ask if mom or dad can help you get incentivized. They want you to get good grades, too!</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Become-a-Book-Editor-Step-5.jpg?ajax=true&aid=16184" href="#/Image:Become-a-Book-Editor-Step-5.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Become a Book Editor Step 5" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/47/Become-a-Book-Editor-Step-5.jpg/aid16184-v4-728px-Become-a-Book-Editor-Step-5.jpg" height="546" id="img_1ff0542967" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_1ff0542967')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Become a Book Editor Step 5" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/47/Become-a-Book-Editor-Step-5.jpg/aid16184-v4-728px-Become-a-Book-Editor-Step-5.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 4" class="step_num">4</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_4"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Work with friends.</b> Studying for tests with friends is super beneficial, so why not do homework with friends, too?! Not only will you stay motivated (and possibly stay interested in the class), but you'll be able to combine your levels of awesome and get things done more quickly, effectively, and possibly creatively.

<ul>
<li>The key here is to choose a friend that will pull his/her weight. You don't want to work with a friend that expects you to do all the work. Nor do you want a friend that wants <i>neither</i> of you to work! Choose a friend that's as goal-oriented as you are.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Write-a-Good-Answer-to-Exam-Essay-Questions-Step-1-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=16184" href="#/Image:Write-a-Good-Answer-to-Exam-Essay-Questions-Step-1-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Write a Good Answer to Exam Essay Questions Step 1" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/cd/Write-a-Good-Answer-to-Exam-Essay-Questions-Step-1-Version-2.jpg/aid16184-v4-728px-Write-a-Good-Answer-to-Exam-Essay-Questions-Step-1-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_9c20bad52c" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_9c20bad52c')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Write a Good Answer to Exam Essay Questions Step 1" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/cd/Write-a-Good-Answer-to-Exam-Essay-Questions-Step-1-Version-2.jpg/aid16184-v4-728px-Write-a-Good-Answer-to-Exam-Essay-Questions-Step-1-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 5" class="step_num">5</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_5"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Don't plagiarize.</b> The quickest way to get a zero on an assignment is to plagiarize it. Technology is amazing nowadays and your teacher <i>will</i> know if you're plagiarizing. Whether it's Google Translate or a speech by Martin Luther King, Jr., they'll know. So don't risk it.

</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
</ol>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>
<a class="anchor" name="Preparing_for_Tests_sub"></a><div class="section steps sticky">
<h3>
<div class="altblock">Part <span>4</span>
</div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="Preparing_for_Tests">Preparing for Tests</span>
</h3>
<div class="section_text" id="steps_4">
<ol class="steps_list_2">
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Be-a-Good-English-Teacher-Step-11-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=16184" href="#/Image:Be-a-Good-English-Teacher-Step-11-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Be a Good English Teacher Step 11" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/44/Be-a-Good-English-Teacher-Step-11-Version-2.jpg/aid16184-v4-728px-Be-a-Good-English-Teacher-Step-11-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_5101e3656a" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_5101e3656a')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Be a Good English Teacher Step 11" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/44/Be-a-Good-English-Teacher-Step-11-Version-2.jpg/aid16184-v4-728px-Be-a-Good-English-Teacher-Step-11-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 1" class="step_num">1</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_4_1"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Study with a friend.</b> There is strength in numbers, even when it comes to studying. Bouncing ideas off each other and combining knowledge is a resource that is invaluable. Just make sure you don't distract each other or spend your whole time chatting with each other about the day!

<ul>
<li>This takes the information off the page and makes it fun and memorable. When you have to explain something to a friend, your brain has to wrap around it, instead of just taking it in and hoping that it stays. Make flashcards and study guides for each other to cover all the material.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div aria-label="Step 2" class="step_num">2</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_4_2"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Use memory tricks.</b> Things like mnemonic devices can really trigger information that doesn't otherwise want to stick. Odds are you probably know Roy G. Biv for the order of the colors of the rainbow or "My very exhausted mother just slept until noon." for the order of the planets. Why is that? They're effective mnemonic devices that stick in your mind!
<ul>
<li>Associations work, too. If you're trying to remember that India used to be a British colony, picture the queen jogging laps around the Taj Mahal. When the test comes, you may not remember what you <i>actually</i> should remember, but you'll remember enough to jog your memory!
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Join-Mensa-Step-13.jpg?ajax=true&aid=16184" href="#/Image:Join-Mensa-Step-13.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Join Mensa Step 13" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/52/Join-Mensa-Step-13.jpg/aid16184-v4-728px-Join-Mensa-Step-13.jpg" height="546" id="img_e13191daf2" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_e13191daf2')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Join Mensa Step 13" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/52/Join-Mensa-Step-13.jpg/aid16184-v4-728px-Join-Mensa-Step-13.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Write-an-Essay-on-Sociology-Step-7.jpg?ajax=true&aid=16184" href="#/Image:Write-an-Essay-on-Sociology-Step-7.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Write an Essay on Sociology Step 7" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/4f/Write-an-Essay-on-Sociology-Step-7.jpg/aid16184-v4-728px-Write-an-Essay-on-Sociology-Step-7.jpg" height="546" id="img_5cbf3ad353" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_5cbf3ad353')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Write an Essay on Sociology Step 7" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/4f/Write-an-Essay-on-Sociology-Step-7.jpg/aid16184-v4-728px-Write-an-Essay-on-Sociology-Step-7.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 3" class="step_num">3</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_4_3"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Study in the places that you feel comfortable in.</b> You need a good, calm place to study. Make sure you have a sweater in case it gets cold, a good, comfy chair, some dark chocolate (brain power!<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 3" class="reference" id="_ref-3"><a href="#_note-3">[3]</a></sup>), a bottle of water, and whatever else you may need. That way, you'll have few interruptions.

<ul>
<li>Research also shows that you should study in <i>more than one</i> place. It sounds a little funny, but your brain makes associations with your environment. So, the more associations it has, the more likely you are to retain the information. Locate all the comfy chairs and study in them all!</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Write-a-Good-Answer-to-Exam-Essay-Questions-Step-12.jpg?ajax=true&aid=16184" href="#/Image:Write-a-Good-Answer-to-Exam-Essay-Questions-Step-12.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Write a Good Answer to Exam Essay Questions Step 12" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/64/Write-a-Good-Answer-to-Exam-Essay-Questions-Step-12.jpg/aid16184-v4-728px-Write-a-Good-Answer-to-Exam-Essay-Questions-Step-12.jpg" height="546" id="img_04017076fb" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_04017076fb')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Write a Good Answer to Exam Essay Questions Step 12" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/64/Write-a-Good-Answer-to-Exam-Essay-Questions-Step-12.jpg/aid16184-v4-728px-Write-a-Good-Answer-to-Exam-Essay-Questions-Step-12.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 4" class="step_num">4</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_4_4"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Stop cramming.</b> Although it's inevitable sometimes, cramming isn't the way to go. In fact, taking breaks is good for your brain and will help you retain <i>more</i>. Try to study in 20-50 minute intervals, taking five or ten minutes in between.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 4" class="reference" id="_ref-4"><a href="#_note-4">[4]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>If you're on top of things, it's best to study over a full week. Several sessions will cement the knowledge in your head and by the end you'll be able to notice how much better you know the content, allowing you to relax and be confident.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Write-a-Good-Thesis-Step-14.jpg?ajax=true&aid=16184" href="#/Image:Write-a-Good-Thesis-Step-14.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Write a Good Thesis Step 14" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/26/Write-a-Good-Thesis-Step-14.jpg/aid16184-v4-728px-Write-a-Good-Thesis-Step-14.jpg" height="546" id="img_f8d4683604" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_f8d4683604')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Write a Good Thesis Step 14" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/26/Write-a-Good-Thesis-Step-14.jpg/aid16184-v4-728px-Write-a-Good-Thesis-Step-14.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 5" class="step_num">5</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_4_5"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Relax.</b> Easier said than done? Remember - you have all of the answers in your head already! The only challenge is getting them out! Your first instinct is nearly always correct. Don't go back and change answers. If you are really not sure, skip it and come back later.

<ul>
<li>Always read the questions given on a test. Skimming over them might tell you the opposite of what you need to do.</li>
<li>If you're uncertain about the wording of a test question, go and ask the teacher what it means. As long as you don't flat out ask for the answer to a question, just what they meant by the question; they will usually answer.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Be-a-Pretty-Teenage-Girl-Step-14.jpg?ajax=true&aid=16184" href="#/Image:Be-a-Pretty-Teenage-Girl-Step-14.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Be a Pretty Teenage Girl Step 14" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/ef/Be-a-Pretty-Teenage-Girl-Step-14.jpg/aid16184-v4-728px-Be-a-Pretty-Teenage-Girl-Step-14.jpg" height="546" id="img_c618da0e76" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_c618da0e76')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Be a Pretty Teenage Girl Step 14" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/ef/Be-a-Pretty-Teenage-Girl-Step-14.jpg/aid16184-v4-728px-Be-a-Pretty-Teenage-Girl-Step-14.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 6" class="step_num">6</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_4_6"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Get a good night's rest.</b> You need sleep in order to stay focused, and without it, you will have a hard time staying on task and may forget what you just learned. That's part of the reason why cramming is so evil!
<ul>
<li>Sleep is wonderful. Sleep deprivation can lead to accidents, dumbs you down, and can actually cause health problems.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 5" class="reference" id="_ref-5"><a href="#_note-5">[5]</a></sup> If you have to choose between one last cramming session and sleep, choose sleep.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
</ol>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>
<a class="anchor" name="Making_Grade-A_Decisions_sub"></a><div class="section steps sticky">
<h3>
<div class="altblock">Part <span>5</span>
</div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="Making_Grade-A_Decisions">Making Grade-A Decisions</span>
</h3>
<div class="section_text" id="steps_5">
<ol class="steps_list_2">
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Be-a-Good-English-Teacher-Step-3-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=16184" href="#/Image:Be-a-Good-English-Teacher-Step-3-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Be a Good English Teacher Step 3" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/4d/Be-a-Good-English-Teacher-Step-3-Version-2.jpg/aid16184-v4-728px-Be-a-Good-English-Teacher-Step-3-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_48fb6cb9b4" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_48fb6cb9b4')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Be a Good English Teacher Step 3" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/4d/Be-a-Good-English-Teacher-Step-3-Version-2.jpg/aid16184-v4-728px-Be-a-Good-English-Teacher-Step-3-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 1" class="step_num">1</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_5_1"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Choose the right classes.</b> In college, though sometimes in high school too, it's tempting to choose classes that look super impressive or are just plain out of your reach. While taking difficult classes is great and you'll learn a lot, limit it to one or two. If all you have is rocket science, you're bound to get overwhelmed. Take Rocket Science 101 and Sand Volleyball. Your brain deserves the break!

<ul>
<li>Choose the right <i>amount</i> of classes, too. Being absolutely time-swamped won't do you any favors. When will you study? Stick to the normal amount (4 or 5 classes per semester for college) and do well in those. It's better to do well in a few than to do mediocre in many.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Write-a-Good-Answer-to-Exam-Essay-Questions-Step-11.jpg?ajax=true&aid=16184" href="#/Image:Write-a-Good-Answer-to-Exam-Essay-Questions-Step-11.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Write a Good Answer to Exam Essay Questions Step 11" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/7e/Write-a-Good-Answer-to-Exam-Essay-Questions-Step-11.jpg/aid16184-v4-728px-Write-a-Good-Answer-to-Exam-Essay-Questions-Step-11.jpg" height="546" id="img_fa9741ea7e" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_fa9741ea7e')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Write a Good Answer to Exam Essay Questions Step 11" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/7e/Write-a-Good-Answer-to-Exam-Essay-Questions-Step-11.jpg/aid16184-v4-728px-Write-a-Good-Answer-to-Exam-Essay-Questions-Step-11.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 2" class="step_num">2</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_5_2"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Get to class on time.</b> The simplest way to get good grades is just to show up to class in the first place. Not only will you get the credit for attendance (hopefully), but you won't miss any imperative announcements, concepts the professor stresses, or bonus questions the teacher includes in class (sneaky buggers, aren't they?).

<ul>
<li>If you're ever on the borderline between grades, <i>going to class will help you</i>. Professors often look at attendance to see if the student's grade should be rounded up or down in questionable circumstances. Give yourself the benefit of the doubt and go!</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Develop-a-Morning-Routine-(Teens)-Step-17.jpg?ajax=true&aid=16184" href="#/Image:Develop-a-Morning-Routine-(Teens)-Step-17.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Develop a Morning Routine (Teens) Step 17" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e8/Develop-a-Morning-Routine-%28Teens%29-Step-17.jpg/aid16184-v4-728px-Develop-a-Morning-Routine-%28Teens%29-Step-17.jpg" height="546" id="img_4df5b71812" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_4df5b71812')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Develop a Morning Routine (Teens) Step 17" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e8/Develop-a-Morning-Routine-%28Teens%29-Step-17.jpg/aid16184-v4-728px-Develop-a-Morning-Routine-%28Teens%29-Step-17.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 3" class="step_num">3</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_5_3"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Eat a good, healthy breakfast every day.</b> It is known that if students eat a good and healthy breakfast every morning, they generally get good grades and are able to focus better in school.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 6" class="reference" id="_ref-6"><a href="#_note-6">[6]</a></sup> Even if you're not hungry early in the morning, bring something with you for later.
<ul>
<li>You want to be not hungry -- not stuffed to the brim and sick. Instead of a six-egg omelet, go for a bowl of cereal and an orange. You'll feel more able to focus on your studies instead of that rock in your stomach.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Improve-Mental-Clarity-Step-9.jpg?ajax=true&aid=16184" href="#/Image:Improve-Mental-Clarity-Step-9.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Improve Mental Clarity Step 9" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b3/Improve-Mental-Clarity-Step-9.jpg/aid16184-v4-728px-Improve-Mental-Clarity-Step-9.jpg" height="546" id="img_16ad200f8c" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_16ad200f8c')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Improve Mental Clarity Step 9" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b3/Improve-Mental-Clarity-Step-9.jpg/aid16184-v4-728px-Improve-Mental-Clarity-Step-9.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 4" class="step_num">4</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_5_4"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb"><a href="/Improve-Your-Memory" title="Improve Your Memory">Improve your memory</a> with games.</b> Give your brain a workout - try some fun puzzle exercises every day such as crosswords, Sudoku, and other games which are easy enough for anyone to do. This will boost your brainpower and you will be able to memorize more information at school.
<ul>
<li>Websites like Lumosity<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 7" class="reference" id="_ref-7"><a href="#_note-7">[7]</a></sup> and Memorize<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 8" class="reference" id="_ref-8"><a href="#_note-8">[8]</a></sup> are great resources! Memorize even lets you input your own information to learn!</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Stay-Focused-on-Writing-Step-8.jpg?ajax=true&aid=16184" href="#/Image:Stay-Focused-on-Writing-Step-8.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Stay Focused on Writing Step 8" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/6b/Stay-Focused-on-Writing-Step-8.jpg/aid16184-v4-728px-Stay-Focused-on-Writing-Step-8.jpg" height="546" id="img_44d0449880" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_44d0449880')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Stay Focused on Writing Step 8" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/6b/Stay-Focused-on-Writing-Step-8.jpg/aid16184-v4-728px-Stay-Focused-on-Writing-Step-8.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 5" class="step_num">5</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_5_5"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Use your time wisely.</b> If you are given an hour to complete a 120-question test, that's 30 seconds per question. 30 seconds can be made into a lot of time. Many of the questions will take far less than 30 seconds, so apply the balance to a tougher question. Don't think too deeply on the time, and don't let yourself get distracted by the ticking of the clock.

<ul>
<li>Time limits are sometimes arbitrary. If you really need an extra 5 minutes, ask. A diligent student that needs a bit more time is a concession most teachers will be willing to make.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage final_li">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Convince-Your-Parents-to-Get-You-an-iPhone-Step-4-Version-3.jpg?ajax=true&aid=16184" href="#/Image:Convince-Your-Parents-to-Get-You-an-iPhone-Step-4-Version-3.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Convince Your Parents to Get You an iPhone Step 4" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/9e/Convince-Your-Parents-to-Get-You-an-iPhone-Step-4-Version-3.jpg/aid16184-v4-728px-Convince-Your-Parents-to-Get-You-an-iPhone-Step-4-Version-3.jpg" height="546" id="img_f0527bc170" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_f0527bc170')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Convince Your Parents to Get You an iPhone Step 4" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/9e/Convince-Your-Parents-to-Get-You-an-iPhone-Step-4-Version-3.jpg/aid16184-v4-728px-Convince-Your-Parents-to-Get-You-an-iPhone-Step-4-Version-3.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 6" class="step_num">6</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_5_6"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Don't be afraid to be great.</b> Don't worry if people think you are a perfectionist or an overachiever. Be persistent with your work while everyone else is fooling around in class. In a few years you will more than likely never see these people again, but you <i>will</i> see the A's and B's on your transcript that could have been C's and D's if you hadn't practiced!
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
</ol>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>
<a class="anchor" name="Questions_and_Answers_sub"></a>
<div class="qa section sticky" data-aid="16184" data-few_contribs="1" data-search_enabled="1">
<h2>
<div class="altblock"></div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="qa_headline">Community Q&A</span>
</h2>
<div class="section_text" id="qa">
<div id="qa_answered_questions_container">
<div id="qa_aq_search_container">
<div class="qa_section_heading" id="qa_aq_search_heading">Search</div>
<input class="qa_aq_search" placeholder="Type your query here"/>
</div>
<a id="qa_add_curated_question"></a>
<ul class="qa_questions qa_aqs qa_waittheresmore" id="qa_article_questions">
<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="60694" data-caid="61567" data-cqid="60711" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="501097" data-submitter_id="0" data-verifier_id="0" data-votes_down="9" data-votes_up="186">
<div class="qa_divider"></div>
<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">How do I avoid thinking about something else while doing revision or homework?</div>
<div class="qa_answers">
<div class="qa_user_area">
<div class="qa_user_hover hint_box"></div>
<div class="qa_badge"></div>
<div class="qa_person_circle"></div>
<div class="qa_answerer_info">
<div class="qa_user_name"></div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Community Answer</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">Remind yourself of your ultimate goal, which is achieving good grades. Remember what matters most to you, and keep in mind the future you are preparing for.</div>
<div class="qa_answer_footer">
<div class="wh_vote_container qa_vote_buttons">
<span class="wh_thumb_response wh_thumb_msg">Thanks!</span>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_links">
<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">Yes</a>
<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">No</a>
</div>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_buttons">
<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box" href="#">Not Helpful <span>9</span></a>
<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box" href="#">Helpful <span>186</span></a>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</li>
<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="15096" data-caid="15963" data-cqid="15107" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="198411" data-submitter_id="0" data-verifier_id="0" data-votes_down="76" data-votes_up="681">
<div class="qa_divider"></div>
<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">How do I stop the voices in my head telling me not to do my homework?</div>
<div class="qa_answers">
<div class="qa_user_area">
<div class="qa_user_hover hint_box"></div>
<div class="qa_badge"></div>
<div class="qa_person_circle"></div>
<div class="qa_answerer_info">
<div class="qa_user_name"></div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Community Answer</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">Think of how not doing your homework will affect your grades, how it could make everything harder on in life. Change the voices too––instead of having them telling you to not do it, change them to telling you that you can do it, will do and that the sooner it's done, the sooner you're free to do something else.</div>
<div class="qa_answer_footer">
<div class="wh_vote_container qa_vote_buttons">
<span class="wh_thumb_response wh_thumb_msg">Thanks!</span>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_links">
<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">Yes</a>
<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">No</a>
</div>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_buttons">
<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box" href="#">Not Helpful <span>76</span></a>
<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box" href="#">Helpful <span>681</span></a>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</li>
<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="16907" data-caid="17778" data-cqid="16922" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="173840" data-submitter_id="0" data-verifier_id="0" data-votes_down="48" data-votes_up="439">
<div class="qa_divider"></div>
<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">How can I avoid making silly mistakes in exams? I am very good in all studies but these small errors keep me back from achieving my goals.</div>
<div class="qa_answers">
<div class="qa_user_area">
<div class="qa_user_hover hint_box"></div>
<div class="qa_badge"></div>
<div class="qa_person_circle"></div>
<div class="qa_answerer_info">
<div class="qa_user_name"></div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Community Answer</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">Read the question slowly and be sure that you understand it. If you aren't sure of the answer to a question and you want to skip it and go to the next question, mark it with a symbol or notation, reminding you to return to it. Leave time at the end of the exam, and go back to the unanswered parts or anything you weren't sure about and deal with those calmly and efficiently. Finally, don't rush, that is how many mistakes happen.</div>
<div class="qa_answer_footer">
<div class="wh_vote_container qa_vote_buttons">
<span class="wh_thumb_response wh_thumb_msg">Thanks!</span>

</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">Aim for small goals, instead of focusing on that A or 100%. If you're struggling in a subject, be proud of any improvement, even a C if you usually fail the tests. Ask for extra credit projects to bring your class grade up.</div>

</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">A teacher who says that isn't modeling good teaching. This is an inappropriate answer to give to a student and if others laugh, ignore them. If people tease you, ask them if they have ever asked a question like that -- most of the time, the answer is yes. Stay back after the class and ask the teacher why they said that, explaining that you have been raised to believe that there is no such thing as a stupid question when learning. If you're really upset about it, you may wish to raise this with your parents or the teacher's superior.  Most teachers won't say this about a question asked by a student.</div>

</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">If it's your friends that are distracting you, try not to sit around them in class. You can talk to them outside of class. If you're just distracted by everything, maybe you should talk to your teacher and see what they suggest and think is the best thing to do.</div>

<div class="qa_answer answer">Take away all the distractions from wherever you are, or if you can't do so, then move to a different place. <div class="section tips sticky">
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Tips">Tips</span></h2>
<div class="section_text" id="tips">
<ul>
<li>Make a document that you can use to track your grades each term to see if you have improved.</li>
<li>Ask your teacher if you can do an essay or extra sheet of problems for extra credit. If he/she says yes, hand it in the next day. If he/she hands it back before the test, you'll see your mistakes and be able to fix them.</li>
<li>Look up extra information about anything you're studying. It will help increase your understanding of the information, make it more interesting, and make it easier to remember. Your teachers will be impressed if you can add information that you didn't learn in class into the essay or test.</li>
<li>Read every night and then ask yourself questions on what you just read to recap. This will also show you how much you need to work on reading comprehension. You may recap what you learnt during walks and while you're engaged in other works.</li>
<li>Having small goals helps. Your goals should try to improve slowly and finally settle on that A. Aiming for an A right away leaves you feeling unrewarded and makes your goal seem unreachable.</li>
<li>Pay attention in your class and try to understand what you teacher is saying/explaining.</li>
<li>Don't worry about competing with people around you, as they may have other goals. Just work hard and try to achieve your goals because you are doing it for you, and you only.</li>
<li>Instead of studying late into the night, go to sleep an hour earlier than usual. Studies show that sleep helps your brain remember from the previous day and clears your mind of stress and anxiety.</li>
<li>Be sure to wake up on time. Oversleeping sometimes makes you even more tired. It's no use being in class drooling all over that test you've been studying for all year!</li>
<li>Write down anything you got wrong on a quiz, test or assignment, and study those things.</li>
<li>The way you know how to do something may not be how your teacher wants you to do it. Depending on the instructor, it may be more important to follow the steps rather than to just get the correct result.</li>
<li>Don't leave the class without really understanding what you learned in there. Ask questions if everyone else doesn't. Be the bigger man and get that knowledge for the future.</li>
<li>Always review your lesson notes at the end of school, and revise them if necessary.</li>
<li>If you do not see improvements at first, <i>don't give up! You'll be proud of yourself when you see your grades improve!</i>
</li>
<li>Even though it might seem like a drag, putting in good effort in the beginning of the year is essential. This will form good habits and you will do well with later material.</li>
</ul>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="section warnings sticky">
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Warnings">Warnings</span></h2>
<div class="section_text" id="warnings">
<ul>
<li>If you do get punished for bad grades, then be sure you strive to try better than you did in the yesteryear. Remember that there's always time for improvement!</li>
<li>Forming bad study habits or disregard for learning and studying will hold you back in the future. Although it seems far off, it's not.</li>
<li>Don't hang around with friends who are not serious in their education. Always stay close to the smart guys, even if your friends laugh at you. It is your grades and future; don't undermine it. What you put in it is what you get out of it.</li>
</ul>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>

<h2>
<a aria-label="Link to edit section Related wikiHows" class="editsection" href="/index.php?title=Get-Good-Grades&action=edit" onclick="gatTrack(gatUser,\'Edit\',\'Edit_section\');" tabindex="-1" title="Edit section: Related wikiHows">Edit</a><span class="mw-headline" id="Related_wikiHows">Related wikiHows</span>
</h2>
<div class="section_text" id="relatedwikihows">

<div id="summary_wrapper"><div id="summary_text">
<h2>Article Summary<a href="#" id="summary_close">X</a>
</h2>
<p>To get good grades, keep a planner with all of your upcoming assignments and tests written in it so you're always prepared. Next, take good notes, and be sure to copy anything the teacher writes on the board. Try to participate in class, to help you remember the information and make a good impression on the teacher. If you can, do your homework right after school so that you don’t forget about it and lose points for late work. <span id="summary_last_sentence">For tips on how to prepare for tests and quizzes, read on!</span><span class="sumpos_bottom" id="summary_position"></span></p>
